title: Maureen Dowd in Conversation with Christine Baranski: Notorious

rawLines.text: [Applause]
hi hi
i wore this in honor of uh Christine
Shell the Gilded Age and Trump's Golden
Era and and my book about glitteries
well let me just say what an honor it is
for me to be here at the Y with you to
help you promote your book and celebrate
your your book and to say that when I
was profiled by Moren I was so
intimidated i thought I'm having lunch
with a woman who was a combination of
Dorothy Parker and Martha Gellhorn and
how am I going to hold my own with you
but you were you were wonderfully easy
and and fun and we've since made a

get that
vibe yeah i I
uh for these pieces I often try and pick
people I admire for their talent or
um you know publicspiritedness and um I
had admired Christine for so long i saw

scene in the garage in Bow Finger is one
of the funniest scenes in the history of
you know I just saw that last night with
my 11-year-old
grandson yes he went Minnie he calls me
Minnie he was stunned to see me up there
with Eddie
can you imagine seeing your grandmother
with Eddie Murphy
with Eddie Murphy eddie Murphy is one of
the pieces in the book and um Christine
is busier than ever and she's won two
Tony's one in me but the prize she's
most proud of she told me is the Polish
Ham
award Miss Polish Ham uh she told me her
biggest ambition now is to play the fool
to Merryill Streep's
Lear and Cynthia Nixon told me about
Christine she's a little girl from

dropped in from
Paris so we bonded over our shared love
of
opera lubboutan
shoes
martinis and we both went back to school
late in life she went to Oxford to study
th Lawrence and Oscar Wild and I went to

just a couple of co-ads here
also we're Catholic we're nice Catholic
girls oh yeah like we like going to
school and we like we like our martinis
yeah absolutely
so I wanted to before we get to the book
because I know you guys are interested
in politics
um a little bit today uh Trump spent his
day doing more than a hundred truth
socials
um retweeting things that pre reposting
things that praised himself so that was
a good day and Elon Musk blamed Zalinski
for a cyber attack on X so not much has
changed since I left
yesterday um but I wanted to ask Diane
um you played
uh Diane Lockheart in The Good Fight and
she was a liberal feminist lawyer
working at a black law firm who suffered
from Trump derangement
syndrome yes if you want to get away
from from the current events you can
binge watch six seasons of of liberal
lawyers going through Trump
derangements and on the guilded age she
plays an old money character who is
unmed by change new money and a value
system based on extravagance and
ambition agnes von Ry and uh Adam Gotnik
wrote a great piece in the New Yorker
about the new guilded age instead of
Morgan Vanderbilt and Carnegie we have
Bezos Musk and
Zuck all of them trying to control the
government in some way so I just wanted
to ask her given your experience with
these two shows what your thoughts are
on our new golden era Gilded Age
or Well I you know I recently rewatched
a lot of the episodes of Good Fight
and I got quite emotional looking at
what we had done because what was
described as a political fantasia on the
theme of right now and it was a show
that was really capturing the the Trump
era and it began with my character
looking at the television set with her
jaw open as Trump was sworn in as
president and six years later it ended
with rioting in the streets and tear gas
and but at the end the two women the two
heads of the law firm Audra whose
character and
mine walking and she she says you you
can't retire now you have to keep up the
good fight and there's this w woman's
firm you can lead a woman's firm in uh
Washington and Diane makes the decision
that she's not going to give up the good
fight but the final shot is Donald Trump
announcing that he's running for
reelection and that was three years ago
and the show had such a wonderful
bookend quality to it and it
really was about what people were living
through so I'm I'm afraid I'm like most
people i'm watching a lot of news these
days you can't not watch what's going on
but I looked at that and I just thought
"Oh my god here we are again." And um
what really struck me is how we
um you know he he was covered rather
like entertainment when he first came
down that escalator i think the media
gave him enormous amount of traction and
we made an entire show about characters
living through the Trump era he was you
know he was our our raw material and
then you've had a million you've have so
many late night monologues and Saturday
Night Live skits and people doing
impersonations and it it really makes me
think to what extent I is he really a
figure is he's he never seemed like a
serious politician or certainly not a
serious statesman
but you know did we did we and make him
a clown an entertainer and and Now it's
deadly serious and he and clearly you
know making jokes about him is a bit
seems a bit inappropriate but I don't
know what your thoughts are on that
Moren because you covered you covered
the whole thing and every everything he
said and did was was covered and he and
you know he got a lot of attention and
attention is now the greatest possible
commodity is to command people's
attention wow I've got your attention
it's pretty cool but uh do you know what
I mean it feels very uh crazy because I
was born in Washington so to have the
city being gutted from the inside out
and not to mention you know the world
instability feels really crazy and
um I was thinking today it's kind of
like the oops we did it again Britney
Spears administration because every day
there's something where
um
Elon like gets rid of the people in
charge of our nuclear safety and Ebola
safety and then he's like oops I didn't
mean to do that you know and Trump um is
the same he he will put tariffs on and
then the next day it's like oops now I'm
taking those off so I can't it's hard
for me to describe the seasickness that
uh people in Washington have because
it's and Trump is very different this
term because he's more confident and
he's got his own people around him and
he's turned the government he sold the
government to the tech titans and he's

take over Greenland and Canada and

how much is is
performative with him because he'll make
these pronouncements and then and he'll
go back on it but it's it's meant to
rock our attention and and it's so
disruptive do you how do you write about
him on you know how do you manage to
just pin him down on any given week and
say I mean your capacity for outrage
must be I know quite exhausted when I
covered
um George W bush and Dick Cheney I was
always in the thesaurus looking for
words that
uh to call him a liar we weren't allowed
to call a president or vice president a
liar then at the times now Trump because
of Trump we can do that so thank you
President Trump
um but you know it's funny because
everyone always asks me um what
Shakespearean figure is Trump like and
um you know often times I ask my
Shakespeare
scholars and they say he's in a

um have uh gotten bored with staying in

they're going to take over the

um in you know uh the summer of
um I went over to I took uh my boss at

Washington
uh chief correspondent to meet him at

uh we went to lunch at Trump Tower and
he had the huge bottle um of

over her head and Mal said "Hispanic
they love me."
you know and then Ivanka came in and met

case there's anything cute in
there i won't be wearing
them." Um but wait I had a few more

so well this is actually about Elon so
there's a very famous picture that went

to Elon was that at the Met Gala it was

wanted to dress me and it happened to be
the night of the Met Gala so I I it was
pretty special night to turn 70 and do
that whole whole thing but um for anyone
who's been to the Met Gala it's it's the
fashion equivalent of the Baton Death
March all you do is you stand and wait
and wait and wait in line to be
photographed and then you go up the
stairs and then you wait and wait and
wait to get into dinner and you're you
know in your high heels and your your
togs and all well I happened to be I did
the gauntlet of the photographers but
um going into dinner I the man standing
next to me said "Oh there's Elon Musk."
And I and I started venting about how
angry I am about the fact that he puts
his money into colonizing space when he
could be putting all that money into
saving the planet and I you know but um
I must have turned around and given him
one more hairy eyeball because a
photographer snapped me and I'm in the
background and Elon Musk is in the
foreground and I'm really have this look
and I'm in a black cape so it's very
gothic looking um anyway it went viral
with a title good versus
evil the good fight and I thought maybe
I should have t-shirts made of that or
if I could afford it I'd put it on a
billboard now it's uh you know um my my
kids gave it to me as a Mother's Day
present they framed it
well that's a weird thing about Elon i
mean in my essay in the book I
interviewed him back in 2017 and then a

Teal and there's an essay on Peter Teal
too uh you know have devoted so much of

yet they've hooked up their fortunes to

that is why your head is always spinning
exorcist style in Washington but anyway
so when I was looking over Christine's
resume
um I noticed something I had missed
which is um you were in the erotic movie
9 and a half weeks
and I was very pregnant at the time and
I was doing this Broadway show The Real

Line he he asked me to be in it i only
have a few scenes with Kim Basinger but
one of them is uh is a dinner scene and
I think it's only my presence in that

during a dinner scene you're you know
looking for for ways to ad lib and keep

and the director wants you to you know
come up with stuff obviously that they

"Well you know I know how to balance a a

because I have this upturned nose." So
he he just thought that was terrific and
it's it's in the movie
so you're in an erotic movie Balancing a

wasn't in the erotic scenes so it's the
least I could do is come up with
something funny
um one more question how is Carrie
Coons spending eight months filming
White Lotus and also able to be on your
show we we finished
um Gilded and then she went off to do

and she got back and went right into the

so she was a very tired she has two
small children so she was you know
that's one of the challenges of being an
actress who's raising a family is you're
you're always torn and it's if you're if
you choose to go on location it's do you
take your kids or don't you take your
kids and I commuted for for years my uh
Matthew my late husband and I raised
children in Connecticut in a little town
of Bethlehem Connecticut and we couldn't
afford as theater actors to live in the
city this was the 80s and things got
very expensive in the 80s because of
Wall Street money you used to be able to
live well in the 70s you could live in
you know rent controlled apartments and
and it was affordable and then the 80s
New York did something else so we raised
the kids in my husband's childhood home
and that meant it was two hours from New
York and I had an active theater career
so I would take a bus
uh at 4:30 get to the Port Authority at
6:30 walk to the theater do the show and
be on an 11:15 bus back
to and then um and then when I did
Hollywood we left the kids and and I
commuted to Hollywood my point being
every actress who's trying to raise a
family faces these really difficult
decisions about you take the kids or you
don't or you're away from the kids and I
have to say I've I've tried to be very
supportive of actresses a little younger
than I who are still doing that i Carrie
uh did um write to me and say I'm I'm in
a real conundrum do I take my little
kids all the way to Thailand and or do I
leave them and I said you know that's
going to be really hard on you and maybe
hard on them to take them and disrupt
their school that's part of the problem
is the disruptive aspect on
them so she did she but she wound up but
she missed them so she commuted from
Thailand to to Bedford New York it's
such a it's it's a really a very
challenging thing to be in show business
and and raise kids and just do that
dance that you have to do holding a
marriage together and and having kids so
it's one of I it's one of my great
achievements was just the fact that I
managed to
have a good life with good kids and a
30-year marriage i consider that as much
of an achievement as all the things on
my resume
um so Esther Newberg will kill me if we

the Drexels were one of the guilded age

dwen and she has a baldini portrait

and uh
anyway that's that but I would love to

um when you So you say that you choose

you're a someone who obviously adores

um
Yeah it's funny because when you

like you are exactly the way I wanted

time and I was sort of nice but then
sometimes it's weird because
uh you know when I was a teenager I had

and I just had been crazy about him my

wasn't really
sexy
because there was so much
incoming you know he had developed kind

and also I think the sex symbol role had

this sex symbol and he could never just
enjoy it and I remember I met him
somewhere to watch his racing team i
forget where it was in the Midwest I
think and um he said "Well just call me
when you're ready to talk or something."
And so I called the operator i said "Can

have an interview with him." Yeah right
sure
so and then we were in the bar at one

racing teammates and you know women just

that wasn't the moment and finally he
just said "I've got to go to my room."
And uh so I could see why that was but
you know sometimes people are like you
you think they will be or want to be and
sometimes they're not i mean in the book
I the only uh one in the book where I
really had an adverse reaction
um was um Kevin Cosner and again I loved

um he was just angry through the whole

getting a private interview he didn't
know what the times was i don't think he
just didn't you know get it and at the

said "Don't worry everyone has a bad

and then he goes "Are you gonna play

And I said "God I said look I
interviewed Paul Newman and I didn't
play that tape for my girlfriend so not
playing this one."
Oh it must it must be interesting when

um I'm trying to think whatever

makeup and hair and

uh in Shakespeare tragedies and

you know it's it's very strange you just

that's a good

no that was a different time it was

because first of all he had to take my

because that was the only bed he could

um was ordering around my assistant i
